children.subject: I agree with false, but I think the reason is because the relationship of the pre- and post- numbers between two nodes has to be contained or disjoint, but never intersect.  A back edge uv would have post(v) > post(u), but the pre(u) would be greater than pre(v).
You are absolutely right. Thanks for pointing it out!
For 5 its O(|V|2) if we use matrix searching and O(V log V + E log V) if we use heap

My answers:

1. False. Below there's an example graph that proves this. Notice how the shortest path from A to C is 6 (AC), but the MST doesn't include AC.

2. True. If $$T$$ is a MST and every edge $$e \in T$$ has unique weight, then for every cut($$S$$, $$\overline{S}$$), $$e$$ is the lightest edge in that cut. If we try to create a new tree $$T' = T \cup e' - e$$, we will end up with $$w(T') = w(T) + w(e') - w(e)$$, and since $$w(e) < w(e')$$, we will get that $$w(T') > w(T)$$ which means that $$T'$$ is not a MST.

3. False. The picture below shows how there can be more than one second best MST:

4. True. We can simply look at the opposite of the weights (by multiplying every weight by -1) and we will end up with a regular MST problem where we already proved (answer #2 above) that the $$T$$ is a unique MST if all the edges have different weights.

5. True. (Maybe?) I think it depends on the specific data structure that we use.

6. True. DFS sets the final post number on a node after it has visited all its connections and there's no other way to go. In a directed acyclic graph, a source node is the only one where DFS will completely stop (because there are no connections coming into the node), therefore the post number of a source node will be higher than the rest of the nodes.

7.  False. For $$e$$ to be an edge between $$u$$ and $$v$$, we need $$post(v) < post(u)$$.

history.content:
I found these questions online. Hope they help you study for the exam.

Select True or False and show your proof:

  1. In an undirected graph, the shortest path between two nodes always lies on some minimum spanning tree.
  2. If all edges of a graph have different weights, the minimum spanning tree is unique.
  3. If all edges of a graph have different weights, the second-best minimum spanning tree is unique.
  4. If all edges of a graph have different weights, then the highest weight spanning tree is unique.
  5. Prim's algorithm for computing minimum spanning trees runs in $$O(|V|^2)$$ steps.
  6. In a DFS on a directed acyclic graph, the vertex with the highest postorder number is necessarily a source.
  7. In a DFS of a directed graph, it is possible to have an edge between two vertices $$u$$ and $$v$$ with pre and post numbers: (10, 40) for $$u$$ and (30, 50) for $$v$$.
history.subject: MST and DFS questions
